headline: Ethiopia condemns US sanctions on Eritrea
summarized_story:
Ethiopia on Saturday denounced new US sanctions on neighbouring Eritrea over Asmara’s role in the deadly conflict pitting Ethiopian forces against Tigrayan rebels, calling on Washington to “rescind its decision”.
Eritrean and Ethiopian forces have been accused of carrying out mass rapes and massacres in Tigray and Washington has repeatedly urged Asmara to withdraw its troops.
On Saturday Eritrea said the sanctions reflected a “misguided and hostile policy” by the US, and were based on false allegations.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has also threatened to impose sanctions against Abiy’s government and the rebels unless they move forward on talks, warning that Ethiopia risks “implosion” if fighting continues.
But Cameron Hudson, a former US official now at the Atlantic Council, said the sanctions had missed the mark.

headline: Strategic leadership helped Nigeria tackle COVID-19 pandemic -Osinbajo
summarized_story:
The Vice President, Yemi Osinbajo has said that Nigeria’s ability to effectively tackle the COVID-19 pandemic was as a result of strategic and responsive leadership.
He said that while many advanced economies were struggling to deal with the fallouts of the global pandemic, the federal government effectively contained the pandemic by deploying a responsive and effective public health framework.
The statement which was issued by the Senior Special Assistant to the President on Media and Publicity, Laolu Akande was titled, ‘Strategic leadership helped Nigeria tackle COVID-19 pandemic – Osinbajo says at retired General’s book presentation.
Buttressing his point on strategic leadership, Osinbajo said such kind of leadership requires imagination, clarity of vision and effective implementation, because of current global challenges, changes and opportunities.
The Vice President further noted that “as a nation, the threats to our corporate existence today are unprecedented and hitherto unimagined.

headline: COVID-19 should not overshadow other health challenges – ECOWAS president
summarized_story:
The President of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) Commission, Jean-Claude Kassi Brou, has said COVID-19 pandemic should not overshadow all the other public health challenges facing the region.
Brou said this on Friday in Abuja, during the 22 Ordinary Session of Assembly of Health Ministers of ECOWAS.
”However, we must redouble our efforts to improving other health indicators in the region, particularly, maternal and child health, fight against communicable, non-communicable, neglected tropical diseases and universal health coverage to mention but a few,” he said.
Brou said that the Public health challenges in the region are colossal and the expectations of the populations are very high.
The ECOWAS President added that the regional integration in health is at the crux of WAHO’s mandate and was part of the essence of the Founding Fathers’ vision.

headline: 2 die, 15 injured in Lagos-Ibadan Expressway accident
summarized_story:
Two persons died while 15 others sustained injuries on Saturday when a speeding DAF truck overturned at a diversion point on the Lagos-Ibadan Expressway.
The vehicle travelling towards Lagos was loaded with bags of onions and passengers when the incident occurred.
The accident which occurred around 6.30 a.m. led to a gridlock as the truck emptied the onions and passengers on the road.

headline: Railway workers give Nigerian government notice of nationwide strike
summarized_story:
Leaders of the National Union of Railway Workers NUR and its Senior Staff Association, SSA, Railway Branch, have directed workers of the Nigeria Railway Corporation, NRC, to embark on a 3-day nationwide strike effective from Thursday, 18th November 2021, over poor welfare.
The National leaders of the two unions directed them to summon a meeting of workers in their districts on Monday, November 15, at 10 am and inform the workers of the impending strike.
The statement said all the workers must comply and stay out of their offices but gather together behind their district union leaders to participate actively, peacefully, and consistently in the whole days of the strike without any fear or let.
The statement warned every district must comply with the notice as any act prejudicial to the notice would be viewed very seriously and strictly by the leadership of the unions.

headline: Osun COVID-19 Isolation Centre shows signs of neglect, deterioration
summarized_story:
The roof of the COVID-19 Isolation Centre built within the premises of the State Hospital, Asubiaro, Osogbo has been blown off.
A recent visit by DAILY POST found the COVID-19 Isolation Centre deteriorated with some parts of the ceilings and windows of the one-year-old structure detached.
Meanwhile, in a separate interview, Dr Rafiu Isamotu, the Commissioner for Health said it was the responsibility of the state government to repair anything that gets damaged at the Isolation Centre.
Isamotu also added that necessary steps have been taken and measures put in place to fix the damaged parts of the centre.
The Isolation centre was built in early 2020 to curtail the spread of the ravaging Coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Nigeria will fulfil climate commitments – Osinbajo insists
summarized_story:
Vice President, Yemi Osinbajo says Nigeria will keep its climate commitments.
The VP, also on Friday, interacted with officials of the International Monetary Fund on the IMF Article IV bilateral consultations.
At both meetings, Osinbajo stated that Nigeria remains committed to helping to reduce global greenhouse emissions.
The agreement comprises a $100 billion per year pledge by wealthier economies to help developing economies respond to climate challenges.

headline: University don advises journalists to adhere to ethics
summarized_story:
A university Don, Dr Isa Saidu at the Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, has enjoined journalists to adhere strictly to the ethics of the profession and take precautionary measures to strike a balance between the profession and survival.
Speaking on a paper titled, “Insecurity and journalism in Nigeria: addressing the dilemma of roving journalists”, Saidu explained that journalists are much interested in crises as they strive to respond to the calling of their profession.
The University don noted that the noble profession of journalism is sometimes a risky adventure, pointing out that the dangers journalists face are not limited to conflict zones.
The chairman of the occasion, Abdurrahman Nuhu Bayero, Dan Iyan Zazzau, advocated for a better pay package for journalists across the country.
He said journalists must also learn to be accurate, balanced and fair in their reportage to justify the trust reposed on them by their teaming audience.

headline: Plateau: Court affirms Laven as Langtang North chairman
summarized_story:
A Jos High Court in Plateau State has affirmed Joshua Ubandoma Laven of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) as the authentic Chairman of Langtang North Local Government Area (LGA).
Justice Ishaku Kunda dismissed an appeal filed by his challenger, Zulfa Bitrus Rimven of the All Progressives Congress (APC) on the ground that the suit was without merit.
Rimven, a lawyer, had approached the court seeking an interpretation of the November 2, 2021 judgment entered in Laven’s favour.
But the judge held that a separate election conducted by the Plateau State Independent Electoral Commission (PLASIEC) for the Langtang North LGA council chair post, which Rimven won, was unnecessary, because, among others, the seat was never vacant.
He ordered Rimven to vacate the office with immediate effect for Laven.

headline: Libya topples Nigeria as Africa's top oil producer
summarized_story:
Libya has overtaken Nigeria as Africa’s top oil producer, according to a new report by the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC).
Libya’s oil production rose to 1.24 million bpd in October from 1.16 million bpd in September.
But according to OPEC secondary sources, Nigeria still pumps more oil than Libya.
Saudi Arabia’s crude oil production rose to 9.759 million bpd, and the Kingdom was quite naturally the producer with the largest monthly increase.
Venezuela boosted its oil production by 57,000 bpd per secondary sources in the OPEC report.

headline: Trump Adviser Bannon Charged after Defying Capitol Riot Subpoena
summarized_story:

Bannon, 67, was charged with one count of contempt of Congress for refusing to appear for a deposition and a second count for refusing to produce documents.
